title: CLAUDE.md
text: file provides guidance Claude Code (claude.ai/code) working code repository.

title: CLAUDE.md
text: blueskynet R package generating analyzing social networks Bluesky Social. package provides tools build networks based user follows relationships, analyze network structures, visualize networks interactive 3D widgets.

title: CLAUDE.md
code: # Load the package for development devtools::load_all()  # Generate documentation from roxygen comments devtools::document()  # Check package for CRAN compliance devtools::check()  # Install the package locally devtools::install()  # Build package documentation website pkgdown::build_site()

title: CLAUDE.md
text: Users must create Bluesky app password set environment variables:
code: # Set environment variables in ~/.Renviron BLUESKY_APP_PASS=your_app_password BLUESKY_APP_USER=your.handle.bsky.social

title: CLAUDE.md
text: package organized four main R files: get_token() - Authentication get_profiles() - User profile data get_follows() - Following relationships get_user_posts() - User post data follow_actor() - Follow users programmatically init_net() - Create initial network key actor expand_net() - Iteratively expand network using keyword filtering build_network() - Complete network building pipeline add_metrics() - Add network analysis metrics trim_net() - Filter networks criteria resp2df() - Convert API responses data frames post2df() - Parse post data API responses check_wait() - Handle API rate limiting Token refresh validation helpers R/blueskynet-package.R - Package documentation imports

title: CLAUDE.md
text: API Token Management: package handles Bluesky authentication access tokens refresh tokens. API functions expect valid token parameter can refresh tokens automatically long-running operations. Network Data Structure: Networks represented tibbles two key columns: - actor_handle - user following - follows_handle - user followed Iterative Network Expansion: expand_net() function uses threshold-based approach grow networks iteratively, filtering new candidates keyword matching user profiles minimum follower counts. Rate Limiting: package includes built-handling Bluesky API rate limits automatic waiting token refresh capabilities.

title: CLAUDE.md
text: package includes comprehensive unit tests using testthat: Key Testing Principles: - 71 comprehensive tests covering major functionality - Mock data approach API functions (avoid live API calls tests) - Edge case coverage including Unicode text, empty inputs, large datasets - Input validation tests proper parameter checking - Performance tests medium-sized networks Test Organization: - tests/testthat/test-helpers.R - Utility functions (word_freqs, etc.) - tests/testthat/test-network-analysis.R - Network algorithms - tests/testthat/test-api-input-validation.R - API wrapper validation - tests/testthat/test-edge-cases.R - Edge cases performance
code: # Run all tests devtools::test()  # Run tests with coverage covr::package_coverage()

title: CLAUDE.md
text: Achievement: 0 errors, 0 warnings R CMD check Critical Issues Watch: 1. Documentation formatting - Use single backslashes roxygen (\describe{} \\describe{}) 2. Examples strategy - Wrap API-dependent examples \dontrun{} 3. Function exports - Ensure documented functions exported 4. Dependencies - used packages must DESCRIPTION Imports 5. ORCID placeholders - Remove replace placeholder ORCID IDs
code: # Key CRAN checks devtools::check(args = "--as-cran") devtools::check_win_devel()  # Optional: check on Windows

title: CLAUDE.md
text: package uses dev/ directory development scripts example data: - dev/demo.R - Complete usage examples - dev/net/ - Sample network data files - Development scripts stress testing error handling

title: CLAUDE.md
text: Uses roxygen2 function documentation pkgdown website generation configured _pkgdown.yml Functions categorized ‚ÄúWrapper functions‚Äù ‚ÄúNetwork functions‚Äù

title: CLAUDE.md
text: Key dependencies include: - httr2 API communication - dplyr, purrr data manipulation - igraph, tidygraph network analysis - threejs 3D network visualization - quanteda text analysis user profiles

title: CLAUDE.md
code: # Authenticate auth_object <- get_token(identifier, password) token <- auth_object$accessJwt  # Create initial network key_actor <- "example.bsky.social" keywords <- c("researcher", "scientist") net <- init_net(key_actor, keywords, token)  # Expand network iteratively expanded <- expand_net(net, keywords, token, refresh_tok,                       threshold = 30, max_iterations = 50)

title: CLAUDE.md
text: Always handle token refresh long-running operations:
code: # Check token validity verify_token(token)  # Refresh if needed new_auth <- refresh_token(refresh_tok) token <- new_auth$accessJwt

title: CLAUDE.md
text: development, several functions enhanced robustness: extract_follow_subjects() Enhancement: Input Validation Pattern:
code: # Before: Used sapply() which could return different types sapply(follow_records, function(record) record$value$subject)  # After: Use vapply() for type safety vapply(follow_records, function(record) record$value$subject, character(1)) # Always validate inputs early in functions if (is.null(follow_records)) {   stop("follow_records cannot be NULL") } if (length(follow_records) == 0) {   return(character(0)) }

title: CLAUDE.md
text: Roxygen2 Guidelines: - Use single backslashes: \describe{}, \item{}, \code{} - Wrap API examples \dontrun{} prevent execution check - Include comprehensive parameter descriptions type information - Add cross-references \seealso function families Example Documentation Pattern:
code: #' @param handle Character vector. Bluesky handles (e.g., "user.bsky.social") #' @param token Character. Authentication token from \code{\link{get_token}} #' #' @return A tibble with user profile information containing: #' \describe{ #'   \item{handle}{Character. User handle} #'   \item{displayName}{Character. Display name} #'   \item{description}{Character. Profile bio} #' } #' #' @examples #' \dontrun{ #' auth <- get_token("your.handle.bsky.social", "your-app-password") #' profiles <- get_profiles("example.bsky.social", auth$accessJwt) #' }

what: Analyze and Visualize Networks on Bluesky Social
title: Analyze and Visualize Networks on Bluesky Social
text: purpose blueskynet provide tools generate analyze networks Bluesky Social,

title: Analyze and Visualize Networks on Bluesky Social
text: can install development version blueskynet like :
code: remotes::install_github("https://github.com/lassehjorthmadsen/blueskynet.git")

title: Analyze and Visualize Networks on Bluesky Social
text: First, create app password : https://bsky.app/settings/app-passwords. , set environment variable BLUESKY_APP_PASS app password, another variable, BLUESKY_APP_USER, identifier (e.g.¬†‚Äúlassehjorthmadsen.bsky.social‚Äù) using file.edit("~/.Renviron") Now, can access core function blueskynet: First rows starting point initial network: ‚Äôre ready, can build bigger net, several supporting artifacts, like 3d-widget, using build_network() won‚Äôt run , since can take lot time build big network.
code: library(blueskynet) library(dplyr)  # Authenticate yourself password <- Sys.getenv("BLUESKY_APP_PASS") identifier <- Sys.getenv("BLUESKY_APP_USER")  # Then get a token and a refresh token auth_object <- get_token(identifier, password) token <- auth_object$accessJwt refresh_tok <- auth_object$refreshJwt  # Establish a small net as a starting point key_actor <- "natalieamiri.bsky.social" keywords <- c("reporter", "journalist", "writer") small_net <- init_net(key_actor, keywords, token) small_net |> head(3) #> # A tibble: 3 √ó 2 #>   actor_handle             follows_handle           #>   <chr>                    <chr>                    #> 1 natalieamiri.bsky.social saschalobo.bsky.social   #> 2 natalieamiri.bsky.social heute.nachrichten.com.de #> 3 natalieamiri.bsky.social iranjournal.bsky.social

what: Add network analysis metrics to user profiles ‚Äî add_metrics
title: Add network analysis metrics to user profiles ‚Äî add_metrics
text: Computes adds comprehensive network analysis metrics user profile data. function calculates centrality measures, community detection, PageRank scores identify influential users network structure within Bluesky social network.

title: Add network analysis metrics to user profiles ‚Äî add_metrics
code: add_metrics(profiles, net)

title: Add network analysis metrics to user profiles ‚Äî add_metrics
text: profiles Tibble. User profile information get_profiles containing least handle profile details net Tibble. Network edge list follow relationships containing: actor_handle Character. User following another follows_handle Character. User followed

title: Add network analysis metrics to user profiles ‚Äî add_metrics
text: Tibble original profile data enhanced network metrics: centrality Numeric. Betweenness centrality score (influence bridge) community Integer. Community assignment cluster analysis pageRank Numeric. PageRank score (influence based follower quality) insideFollowers Integer. Number followers within network community_label Character. Descriptive label community Plus original profile columns (handle, displayName, description, etc.)

title: Add network analysis metrics to user profiles ‚Äî add_metrics
text: function performs several network analysis computations: Betweenness centrality: Identifies users act bridges communities Community detection: Uses random walks find densely connected groups PageRank: Measures influence based follower network quality Inside followers: Counts followers within analyzed network subset Community labels: Generates descriptive labels using TF-IDF user bios

title: Add network analysis metrics to user profiles ‚Äî add_metrics
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Build a network first auth <- get_token("your.handle.bsky.social", "your-app-password") network_result <- build_network(   key_actors = c("scientist.bsky.social", "researcher.bsky.social"),   keywords = c("science", "research", "academic"),   token = auth$accessJwt,   refresh_tok = auth$refreshJwt,   threshold = 10 )  # Add comprehensive metrics to profiles enhanced_profiles <- add_metrics(network_result$profiles, network_result$net)  # Examine the most central (influential) users top_central <- enhanced_profiles[   order(enhanced_profiles$centrality, decreasing = TRUE), ][1:10, c("displayName", "handle", "centrality", "pageRank")] print(top_central)  # Find the most influential users by PageRank top_pagerank <- enhanced_profiles[   order(enhanced_profiles$pageRank, decreasing = TRUE), ][1:10, c("displayName", "handle", "pageRank", "followersCount")] print(top_pagerank)  # Analyze community structure community_summary <- enhanced_profiles |>   group_by(community, community_label) |>   summarise(     members = n(),     avg_followers = mean(followersCount, na.rm = TRUE),     avg_centrality = mean(centrality, na.rm = TRUE),     .groups = "drop"   ) |>   arrange(desc(members)) print(community_summary)  # Find users who bridge communities (high centrality) bridge_users <- enhanced_profiles[   enhanced_profiles$centrality > quantile(enhanced_profiles$centrality, 0.9, na.rm = TRUE),   c("displayName", "handle", "centrality", "community_label") ] print(bridge_users)  # Compare internal vs external influence influence_comparison <- enhanced_profiles |>   select(handle, followersCount, insideFollowers, pageRank) |>   mutate(     external_followers = followersCount - insideFollowers,     influence_ratio = insideFollowers / followersCount   ) |>   arrange(desc(influence_ratio)) head(influence_comparison, 10) } # }

what: blueskynet: Analyze and Visualize Networks on Bluesky Social ‚Äî blueskynet-package
title: blueskynet: Analyze and Visualize Networks on Bluesky Social ‚Äî blueskynet-package
text: Provides comprehensive tools collecting, analyzing, visualizing social networks Bluesky Social https://bsky.app. Enables users authenticate Bluesky API, collect follower networks, perform community detection, calculate network metrics, create interactive 3D visualizations. Includes functions network expansion algorithms, text analysis user profiles, follow/unfollow management. Designed social network researchers, data scientists, anyone interested understanding social structures Bluesky Social.

title: blueskynet: Analyze and Visualize Networks on Bluesky Social ‚Äî blueskynet-package
text: Maintainer: Lasse Hjorth Madsen lassehjorthmadsen@gmail.com

what: Build complete network analysis pipeline ‚Äî build_network
title: Build complete network analysis pipeline ‚Äî build_network
text: Executes complete network analysis workflow: initializes network key actors, expands iteratively, trims final size, gets detailed profiles, creates visualizations, generates text analysis. main high-level function comprehensive Bluesky network analysis.

title: Build complete network analysis pipeline ‚Äî build_network
code: build_network(key_actors, keywords, token, refresh_tok, threshold, prop, ...)

title: Build complete network analysis pipeline ‚Äî build_network
text: key_actors Character vector. Handles central users start network keywords Character vector. Keywords filtering users network token Character. Authentication token get_token refresh_tok Character. Refresh token long-running operations threshold Numeric. Inclusion threshold network expansion: >= 1 Minimum followers existing network required < 1 Proportion network must follow prospect prop Numeric. Proportion users sample 3D visualization (0-1, 1.0 includes users) ... Additional parameters passed expand_net (e.g., max_iterations, sample_size, save_net)

title: Build complete network analysis pipeline ‚Äî build_network
text: comprehensive list containing network analysis results: net Tibble. Final expanded network follow relationships profiles Tibble. Detailed profile information network members metrics Tibble. Network metrics (centrality, community detection) widget HTML widget. Interactive 3D network visualization word_analysis Tibble. Word frequency analysis profile descriptions token Character. Updated access token refresh_tok Character. Updated refresh token

title: Build complete network analysis pipeline ‚Äî build_network
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Complete network analysis for science communicators auth <- get_token("your.handle.bsky.social", "your-app-password")  # Build comprehensive network science_network <- build_network(   key_actors = c("example.scientist.bsky.social", "researcher.bsky.social"),   keywords = c("research", "science", "academic", "PhD", "university"),   token = auth$accessJwt,   refresh_tok = auth$refreshJwt,   threshold = 10,      # Need 10+ mutual follows for inclusion   prop = 0.5,          # Sample 50% for visualization   max_iterations = 15, # Limit expansion iterations   save_net = TRUE      # Save progress incrementally )  # Explore the results print(paste("Network has", nrow(science_network$net), "connections")) print(paste("Among", nrow(science_network$profiles), "unique users"))  # View the interactive visualization science_network$widget  # Examine top words in user descriptions head(science_network$word_analysis, 20)  # Find most central users top_central <- science_network$profiles[   order(science_network$profiles$betweenness, decreasing = TRUE), ][1:10, c("displayName", "handle", "description")] print(top_central) } # }

what: Generate labels for network communities ‚Äî com_labels
title: Generate labels for network communities ‚Äî com_labels
text: Creates descriptive labels network communities analyzing frequent words (using TF-IDF weighting) user profile descriptions within community.

title: Generate labels for network communities ‚Äî com_labels
code: com_labels(profiles, top = 3)

title: Generate labels for network communities ‚Äî com_labels
text: profiles Data frame tibble profile information, must contain: community Integer. Community assignment user description Character. User profile descriptions/bios analyze top Integer. Number top words include label (default 3)

title: Generate labels for network communities ‚Äî com_labels
text: tibble community labels: community Integer. Community ID community_label Character. Descriptive label top keywords

title: Generate labels for network communities ‚Äî com_labels
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Authenticate first auth <- get_token("your.handle.bsky.social", "your-app-password")  # Build a network to get community-assigned profiles network_result <- build_network(   key_actors = c("scientist.bsky.social", "researcher.bsky.social"),   keywords = c("science", "research", "academic"),   token = auth$accessJwt,   refresh_tok = auth$refreshJwt,   threshold = 10 )  # Add network metrics to get community assignments profiles_with_communities <- add_metrics(network_result$profiles, network_result$net)  # Generate descriptive labels for each community community_labels <- com_labels(profiles_with_communities, top = 3) print(community_labels)  # View the most common words for each community head(community_labels) } # }

what: Create interactive 3D network visualization widget ‚Äî create_widget
title: Create interactive 3D network visualization widget ‚Äî create_widget
text: Creates interactive 3D visualization Bluesky social network using WebGL. visualization shows users nodes colored community membership connections edges, allowing explore network structure, identify clusters, understand relationship patterns social network.

title: Create interactive 3D network visualization widget ‚Äî create_widget
code: create_widget(net, profiles, prop = 1)

title: Create interactive 3D network visualization widget ‚Äî create_widget
text: net Tibble. Network edge list follow relationships containing: actor_handle Character. User following another follows_handle Character. User followed profiles Tibble. User profile information get_profiles containing handle, displayName, description profile details prop Numeric. Proportion users include visualization (0-1). Use smaller values large networks improve performance (default 1.0)

title: Create interactive 3D network visualization widget ‚Äî create_widget
text: interactive HTML widget (threejs object) displays: Nodes representing users, colored community Edges representing follow relationships Interactive controls rotation, zoom, exploration Hover tooltips showing user information

title: Create interactive 3D network visualization widget ‚Äî create_widget
text: visualization process includes: Community detection using random walk algorithm Color assignment based community membership Node labeling user display names descriptions 3D layout generation optimal viewing large networks (1000+ users), consider using prop < 1 sample subset better performance. widget works best networks 50-500 users detailed exploration.

title: Create interactive 3D network visualization widget ‚Äî create_widget
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Build a network for visualization auth <- get_token("your.handle.bsky.social", "your-app-password") network <- build_network(   key_actors = c("scientist.bsky.social", "researcher.bsky.social"),   keywords = c("science", "research", "academic"),   token = auth$accessJwt,   refresh_tok = auth$refreshJwt,   threshold = 15,   prop = 0.3  # Sample 30% for manageable size )  # Create full network visualization full_widget <- create_widget(network$net, network$profiles, prop = 1.0)  # Display the interactive visualization full_widget  # Create smaller sample for performance sample_widget <- create_widget(network$net, network$profiles, prop = 0.5) sample_widget  # For very large networks, use even smaller samples if (nrow(network$profiles) > 500) {   performance_widget <- create_widget(network$net, network$profiles, prop = 0.2) } else {   performance_widget <- create_widget(network$net, network$profiles, prop = 0.8) }  # Save widget as HTML file for sharing if (requireNamespace("htmlwidgets", quietly = TRUE)) {   htmlwidgets::saveWidget(full_widget, "network_visualization.html")   message("Visualization saved as network_visualization.html") }  # Customize for specific communities # Filter to show only the largest communities profiles_with_metrics <- add_metrics(network$profiles, network$net) large_communities <- profiles_with_metrics[   profiles_with_metrics$community %in% c(1, 2, 3),  # Top 3 communities ] filtered_net <- network$net[   network$net$actor_handle %in% large_communities$handle &   network$net$follows_handle %in% large_communities$handle, ] focused_widget <- create_widget(filtered_net, large_communities, prop = 1.0) focused_widget } # }

what: Expand network through iterative growth ‚Äî expand_net
title: Expand network through iterative growth ‚Äî expand_net
text: Expands initial network iteratively finding new users followed many existing network members match specified keywords. core algorithm growing networks seed set users.

title: Expand network through iterative growth ‚Äî expand_net
code: expand_net(   net,   keywords,   token,   refresh_tok,   save_net = FALSE,   file_name,   threshold,   max_iterations,   sample_size = Inf )

title: Expand network through iterative growth ‚Äî expand_net
text: net Tibble. Initial network follow relationships, must contain: actor_handle Character. User following follows_handle Character. User followed keywords Character vector. Keywords search user profile descriptions determine network membership eligibility token Character. Authentication token get_token refresh_tok Character. Refresh token get_token long-running operations save_net Logical. network saved incrementally expansion prevent data loss? (default FALSE) file_name Character. File path incremental saves. provided, defaults 'dev/net/bignet_TIMESTAMP.rds' threshold Numeric. Inclusion threshold new users: >= 1 Minimum number existing network members must follow prospect < 1 Fraction network members must follow prospect max_iterations Integer. Maximum number expansion iterations (default 50) sample_size Integer. Maximum prospects consider per iteration. Use Inf limit (default), smaller values testing

title: Expand network through iterative growth ‚Äî expand_net
text: list containing expanded network results: net Tibble. Expanded network follow relationships discovered token Character. Updated access token (may refreshed) refresh_tok Character. Updated refresh token profiles Tibble. Profile information network members iterations Integer. Number iterations completed

title: Expand network through iterative growth ‚Äî expand_net
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Start with an initial network auth <- get_token("your.handle.bsky.social", "your-app-password") token <- auth$accessJwt refresh_tok <- auth$refreshJwt  # Create initial network initial <- init_net("example.scientist.bsky.social",                     c("research", "science"), token)  # Expand the network - conservative approach expanded <- expand_net(   net = initial,   keywords = c("research", "science", "academic", "PhD"),   token = token,   refresh_tok = refresh_tok,   threshold = 5,        # Need 5+ followers from existing network   max_iterations = 10,  # Limit iterations for testing   save_net = TRUE       # Save progress incrementally )  print(paste("Network grew from", nrow(initial), "to",             nrow(expanded$net), "connections"))  # More aggressive expansion with lower threshold large_expansion <- expand_net(   net = expanded$net,   keywords = c("research", "science", "academic"),   token = expanded$token,   refresh_tok = expanded$refresh_tok,   threshold = 0.1,      # 10% of network must follow prospect   max_iterations = 25 ) } # }

what: Extract subject DIDs from follow records ‚Äî extract_follow_subjects
title: Extract subject DIDs from follow records ‚Äî extract_follow_subjects
text: Extracts DIDs (decentralized identifiers) users following complete follow records retrieved get_all_follow_records. useful getting simple list follow analysis bulk operations without full record metadata.

title: Extract subject DIDs from follow records ‚Äî extract_follow_subjects
code: extract_follow_subjects(follow_records)

title: Extract subject DIDs from follow records ‚Äî extract_follow_subjects
text: follow_records List. Output get_all_follow_records containing complete follow record objects

title: Extract subject DIDs from follow records ‚Äî extract_follow_subjects
text: Character vector DIDs users following. unique identifier like ":plc:abc123xyz..."

title: Extract subject DIDs from follow records ‚Äî extract_follow_subjects
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Authenticate first auth <- get_token("your.handle.bsky.social", "your-app-password") token <- auth$accessJwt my_did <- auth$did  # Get all your follow records all_follows <- get_all_follow_records(my_did, token) print(paste("You have", length(all_follows), "follow records"))  # Extract just the DIDs of people you follow followed_dids <- extract_follow_subjects(all_follows) print(paste("You are following", length(followed_dids), "unique users")) head(followed_dids, 5)  # Use DIDs to get detailed profile information sample_profiles <- get_profiles(followed_dids[1:10], token) print(sample_profiles[, c("displayName", "handle", "followersCount")])  # Count follows by domain handles_from_dids <- get_profiles(followed_dids, token)$handle domains <- sapply(strsplit(handles_from_dids, "\\\\."), function(x) {   if (length(x) >= 2) paste(tail(x, 2), collapse = ".") else x[1] }) domain_counts <- sort(table(domains), decreasing = TRUE) head(domain_counts, 10)  # Find users you follow who follow each other (mutual connections) mutual_matrix <- matrix(FALSE, length(followed_dids), length(followed_dids)) for (i in seq_along(followed_dids)) {   user_follows <- get_follows(followed_dids[i], token)   if (!is.null(user_follows)) {     user_follow_dids <- get_profiles(user_follows$handle, token)$did     mutual_matrix[i, ] <- followed_dids %in% user_follow_dids   }   Sys.sleep(1) # Rate limiting } } # }

what: Find follow record for specific actor ‚Äî find_follow_record
title: Find follow record for specific actor ‚Äî find_follow_record
text: Searches complete follow records find specific record given user. essential unfollow operations since need record key (rkey) original follow record delete .

title: Find follow record for specific actor ‚Äî find_follow_record
code: find_follow_record(follow_records, actor_did)

title: Find follow record for specific actor ‚Äî find_follow_record
text: follow_records List. Output get_all_follow_records containing follow record objects actor_did Character. (decentralized identifier) user want find follow record

title: Find follow record for specific actor ‚Äî find_follow_record
text: complete follow record object found, \codeNULL user follows. record contains: uri Character. Record URI containing rkey needed unfollowing cid Character. Content identifier value List. Record metadata including subject creation time

title: Find follow record for specific actor ‚Äî find_follow_record
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Authenticate first auth <- get_token("your.handle.bsky.social", "your-app-password") token <- auth$accessJwt my_did <- auth$did  # Get all your follow records all_follows <- get_all_follow_records(my_did, token)  # Find a specific user's profile to get their DID target_profile <- get_profiles("example.bsky.social", token) target_did <- target_profile$did  # Find the follow record for that user follow_record <- find_follow_record(all_follows, target_did)  if (!is.null(follow_record)) {   message("Found follow record for user!")    # Extract the rkey needed for unfollowing   rkey <- basename(follow_record$uri)   message("Record key: ", rkey)    # Unfollow the user   result <- unfollow_actor(my_did, rkey, token)   if (!is.null(result)) {     message("Successfully unfollowed user!")   } } else {   message("You are not following this user") }  # Batch processing: check if you follow multiple users users_to_check <- c("user1.bsky.social", "user2.bsky.social", "user3.bsky.social") check_profiles <- get_profiles(users_to_check, token)  follow_status <- data.frame(   handle = check_profiles$handle,   following = sapply(check_profiles$did, function(did) {     !is.null(find_follow_record(all_follows, did))   }) ) print(follow_status)  # Conditional unfollowing based on criteria followed_dids <- extract_follow_subjects(all_follows) followed_profiles <- get_profiles(followed_dids[1:50], token)  # Sample for demo  # Unfollow users with very low activity (< 5 posts) inactive_users <- followed_profiles[followed_profiles$postsCount < 5, ]  for (did in inactive_users$did) {   record <- find_follow_record(all_follows, did)   if (!is.null(record)) {     rkey <- basename(record$uri)     unfollow_actor(my_did, rkey, token)     message("Unfollowed inactive user: ", inactive_users$handle[inactive_users$did == did])     Sys.sleep(1) # Rate limiting   } } } # }

what: Follow a user on Bluesky Social ‚Äî follow_actor
title: Follow a user on Bluesky Social ‚Äî follow_actor
text: Creates follow relationship account another user Bluesky Social. equivalent clicking "Follow" button user's profile.

title: Follow a user on Bluesky Social ‚Äî follow_actor
code: follow_actor(my_did, actor_did, token)

title: Follow a user on Bluesky Social ‚Äî follow_actor
text: my_did Character. decentralized identifier () obtained get_token response actor_did Character. user want follow. Can obtained using get_profiles token Character. Authentication token get_token

title: Follow a user on Bluesky Social ‚Äî follow_actor
text: httr2 response object containing: uri Character. URI created follow record cid Character. Content identifier follow record Returns NULL follow operation fails.

title: Follow a user on Bluesky Social ‚Äî follow_actor
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Authenticate first auth <- get_token("your.handle.bsky.social", "your-app-password") token <- auth$accessJwt my_did <- auth$did  # Get the DID of the user you want to follow target_profile <- get_profiles("neilhimself.neilgaiman.com", token) target_did <- target_profile$did  # Follow the user result <- follow_actor(my_did, target_did, token)  if (!is.null(result)) {   message("Successfully followed user!") }  # Follow multiple users users_to_follow <- c("user1.bsky.social", "user2.bsky.social") profiles <- get_profiles(users_to_follow, token)  for (i in 1:nrow(profiles)) {   result <- follow_actor(my_did, profiles$did[i], token)   Sys.sleep(1) # Be respectful with rate limits } } # }

what: Get complete follow records from user repository ‚Äî get_all_follow_records
title: Get complete follow records from user repository ‚Äî get_all_follow_records
text: Retrieves follow records user's personal repository Bluesky. provides detailed follow relationship data get_follows, including record keys needed unfollow_actor operations. Useful follow/unfollow management relationship analysis.

title: Get complete follow records from user repository ‚Äî get_all_follow_records
code: get_all_follow_records(my_did, token, max_retries = 3, retry_delay = 5)

title: Get complete follow records from user repository ‚Äî get_all_follow_records
text: my_did Character. decentralized identifier () get_token response token Character. Authentication token get_token max_retries Integer. Maximum number retries failure (default 3) retry_delay Numeric. Delay seconds retries (default 5)

title: Get complete follow records from user repository ‚Äî get_all_follow_records
text: list follow record objects, containing: uri Character. Unique record identifier (contains rkey) cid Character. Content identifier value List. Record content 'subject' (target ) metadata record represents one follow relationship created.

title: Get complete follow records from user repository ‚Äî get_all_follow_records
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Authenticate first auth <- get_token("your.handle.bsky.social", "your-app-password") token <- auth$accessJwt my_did <- auth$did  # Get all your follow records all_follows <- get_all_follow_records(my_did, token) print(paste("You are following", length(all_follows), "users"))  # Extract just the DIDs of people you follow followed_dids <- extract_follow_subjects(all_follows) head(followed_dids)  # Find a specific follow record target_profile <- get_profiles("example.bsky.social", token) target_record <- find_follow_record(all_follows, target_profile$did)  if (!is.null(target_record)) {   # Unfollow using the record key   rkey <- basename(target_record$uri)   unfollow_actor(my_did, rkey, token) }  # Bulk unfollow inactive users (example workflow) recent_active <- get_profiles(followed_dids[1:50], token) old_follows <- recent_active[recent_active$postsCount < 5, ]  for (did in old_follows$did) {   record <- find_follow_record(all_follows, did)   if (!is.null(record)) {     rkey <- basename(record$uri)     unfollow_actor(my_did, rkey, token)     Sys.sleep(1) # Rate limiting   } } } # }

Number followers follower followsCount Integer. Number accounts follower follows createdAt Character. follow relationship created Returns NULL user exist inaccessible.

title: Get followers of a Bluesky user ‚Äî get_followers
text: lexicons/app/bsky/graph/getFollowers.json

title: Get followers of a Bluesky user ‚Äî get_followers
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Authenticate first auth <- get_token("your.handle.bsky.social", "your-app-password") token <- auth$accessJwt  # Get followers of a popular account followers <- get_followers("neilhimself.neilgaiman.com", token) print(paste("User has", nrow(followers), "followers"))  # Analyze follower demographics follower_profiles <- get_profiles(followers$handle[1:100], token) print(summary(follower_profiles$followersCount))  # Compare follows vs followers for reciprocity analysis user_handle <- "example.bsky.social" follows <- get_follows(user_handle, token) followers <- get_followers(user_handle, token)  # Find mutual connections (people who follow each other) mutual <- intersect(follows$handle, followers$handle) print(paste("Mutual connections:", length(mutual)))  # Identify influential followers (high follower count) influential <- followers[followers$followersCount > 1000, ] head(influential[, c("displayName", "handle", "followersCount")]) } # }

text: actors Character vector. User handles (e.g., "username.bsky.social") DIDs users whose profiles want retrieve token Character. Authentication token get_token chunksize Integer. Number actors per API request batch processing (default 25, current API maximum) max_retries Integer. Number times retry failure (default 3) retry_delay Numeric. Delay seconds retries (default 5)

title: Get profile information for Bluesky users ‚Äî get_profiles
text: tibble detailed profile information: handle Character. User's handle (e.g., "user.bsky.social") Character. User's decentralized identifier displayName Character. User's display name description Character. User's bio/profile description avatar Character. URL user's avatar image banner Character. URL user's banner image followersCount Integer. Number followers followsCount Integer. Number accounts follow postsCount Integer. Number posts made createdAt Character. account created Returns NULL users exist inaccessible.

title: Get profile information for Bluesky users ‚Äî get_profiles
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Authenticate first auth <- get_token("your.handle.bsky.social", "your-app-password") token <- auth$accessJwt  # Get profile for a single user profile <- get_profiles("neilhimself.neilgaiman.com", token) print(profile)  # Get profiles for multiple users efficiently users <- c("user1.bsky.social", "user2.bsky.social", "user3.bsky.social") profiles <- get_profiles(users, token) head(profiles)  # Use with network analysis follows <- get_follows("example.bsky.social", token) detailed_profiles <- get_profiles(follows$handle, token)  # Filter by follower count popular_users <- profiles[profiles$followersCount > 1000, ] } # }

what: Get authentication token for Bluesky API ‚Äî get_token

title: Get authentication token for Bluesky API ‚Äî get_token
code: get_token(identifier, password)

title: Get authentication token for Bluesky API ‚Äî get_token
text: identifier Character. Bluesky handle (e.g., "username.bsky.social") email address password Character. Bluesky app password (regular password). Create one https://bsky.app/settings/app-passwords

title: Get authentication token for Bluesky API ‚Äî get_token
text: list containing authentication information: accessJwt Character. Access token API calls refreshJwt Character. Refresh token renewing access handle Character. verified handle Character. decentralized identifier () email Character. email address

title: Get authentication token for Bluesky API ‚Äî get_token
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Authenticate with Bluesky (requires valid credentials) auth <- get_token("your.handle.bsky.social", "your-app-password")  # Extract tokens for use in other functions access_token <- auth$accessJwt refresh_token <- auth$refreshJwt my_did <- auth$did  # Verify the token works verify_token(access_token) } # }

what: Retrieve posts from a Bluesky user ‚Äî get_user_posts
title: Retrieve posts from a Bluesky user ‚Äî get_user_posts
text: Fetches posts specific user's timeline Bluesky Social various filtering options. Useful content analysis, engagement tracking, understanding user posting patterns. Includes pagination support large post histories robust error handling reliable data collection.

title: Retrieve posts from a Bluesky user ‚Äî get_user_posts
code: get_user_posts(   actor,   token,   max_retries = 3,   retry_delay = 5,   filter = "posts_no_replies",   limit = 100,   return_df = TRUE )

title: Retrieve posts from a Bluesky user ‚Äî get_user_posts
text: actor Character. User handle (e.g., "username.bsky.social") user whose posts want retrieve token Character. Authentication token get_token max_retries Integer. Number times retry failure (default 3) retry_delay Numeric. Delay seconds retries (default 5) filter Character. Type posts retrieve (default "posts_no_replies"): posts_no_replies Original posts , replies posts_with_replies posts including replies posts_with_media Posts containing images videos posts_and_author_threads Posts thread continuations posts_with_video Posts containing video content limit Integer. Maximum number posts retrieve (default 100) return_df Logical. Return tibble (TRUE) raw JSON list (FALSE)

title: Retrieve posts from a Bluesky user ‚Äî get_user_posts
text: return_df = TRUE, tibble post information: actor Character. user made post uri Character. Unique post identifier cid Character. Content identifier author_did Character. Author's author_handle Character. Author's handle author_displayName Character. Author's display name text Character. Post text content created_at Character. post created reply_count Integer. Number replies repost_count Integer. Number reposts like_count Integer. Number likes quote_count Integer. Number quote posts return_df = FALSE, returns raw JSON response list.

title: Retrieve posts from a Bluesky user ‚Äî get_user_posts
text: Endpoint documentation

title: Retrieve posts from a Bluesky user ‚Äî get_user_posts
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Authenticate first auth <- get_token("your.handle.bsky.social", "your-app-password") token <- auth$accessJwt  # Get recent posts from a user (no replies) posts <- get_user_posts("neilhimself.neilgaiman.com", token, limit = 50) head(posts[, c("text", "created_at", "like_count")])  # Get posts with media content media_posts <- get_user_posts("photographer.bsky.social", token,                               filter = "posts_with_media", limit = 20)  # Analyze posting patterns user_posts <- get_user_posts("example.bsky.social", token, limit = 200)  # Most engaging posts top_posts <- user_posts[order(user_posts$like_count, decreasing = TRUE), ] head(top_posts[, c("text", "like_count", "repost_count")], 10)  # Text analysis of posts post_words <- word_freqs(user_posts$text, top = 20) head(post_words)  # Get raw JSON for custom processing raw_posts <- get_user_posts("example.bsky.social", token,                             return_df = FALSE, limit = 10) str(raw_posts[[1]]) # Examine structure } # }

what: Initialize a network from key actors ‚Äî init_net
title: Initialize a network from key actors ‚Äî init_net
text: Creates initial network getting accounts key actors follow, filtering accounts based profile keywords. forms seed network can later expanded using expand_net.

title: Initialize a network from key actors ‚Äî init_net
code: init_net(key_actors, keywords, token, refresh_tok)

title: Initialize a network from key actors ‚Äî init_net
text: key_actors Character vector. Handles (e.g., "username.bsky.social") central actors whose follows form initial network keywords Character vector. Keywords search user profile descriptions determine included network token Character. Authentication token get_token refresh_tok Character. Refresh token get_token long-running operations. Token refreshed automatically processing prevent expiration large numbers key actors.

title: Initialize a network from key actors ‚Äî init_net
text: list containing initial network results: net Tibble. Network edges follow relationships token Character. Updated access token (may refreshed) refresh_tok Character. Updated refresh token net tibble contains: actor_handle Character. Handle user following follows_handle Character. Handle user followed represents initial network structure row follow relationship two users.

title: Initialize a network from key actors ‚Äî init_net
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Authenticate first auth <- get_token("your.handle.bsky.social", "your-app-password") token <- auth$accessJwt refresh_tok <- auth$refreshJwt  # Create initial network from science communicators key_scientists <- c("neilhimself.neilgaiman.com", "example.scientist.bsky.social") science_keywords <- c("scientist", "researcher", "academic", "PhD")  result <- init_net(key_scientists, science_keywords, token, refresh_tok) initial_net <- result$net token <- result$token  # Updated token refresh_tok <- result$refresh_tok  # Updated refresh token  print(paste("Initial network has", nrow(initial_net), "connections"))  # Examine the network structure unique_actors <- length(unique(c(initial_net$actor_handle, initial_net$follows_handle))) print(paste("Network contains", unique_actors, "unique users")) } # }

what: Refresh authentication token for Bluesky API ‚Äî refresh_token
title: Refresh authentication token for Bluesky API ‚Äî refresh_token
text: Refreshes expired access token using refresh token. Access tokens expire period time, refresh tokens can used obtain new access tokens without re-authenticating.

title: Refresh authentication token for Bluesky API ‚Äî refresh_token
code: refresh_token(refresh_token)

title: Refresh authentication token for Bluesky API ‚Äî refresh_token
text: refresh_token Character. refresh token obtained get_token

title: Refresh authentication token for Bluesky API ‚Äî refresh_token
text: list containing new authentication information: accessJwt Character. New access token API calls refreshJwt Character. New refresh token future renewals handle Character. verified handle Character. decentralized identifier ()

title: Refresh authentication token for Bluesky API ‚Äî refresh_token
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # First authenticate to get tokens auth <- get_token("your.handle.bsky.social", "your-app-password")  # Later, when access token expires, refresh it new_auth <- refresh_token(auth$refreshJwt) new_access_token <- new_auth$accessJwt  # Use the new token for API calls profiles <- get_profiles("example.bsky.social", new_access_token) } # }

what: Clean and trim network to create cohesive community ‚Äî trim_net
title: Clean and trim network to create cohesive community ‚Äî trim_net
text: Iteratively refines network removing isolated users applying follower thresholds create cohesive community every user follows followed others within network. produces cleaner network visualizations meaningful community analysis.

title: Clean and trim network to create cohesive community ‚Äî trim_net
code: trim_net(net, threshold)

title: Clean and trim network to create cohesive community ‚Äî trim_net
text: net Tibble. Network edge list follow relationships containing: actor_handle Character. User following another follows_handle Character. User followed threshold Numeric. Inclusion threshold users: >= 1 Minimum number followers within network required < 1 Minimum proportion network must follow user

title: Clean and trim network to create cohesive community ‚Äî trim_net
text: Tibble. Cleaned network structure input : duplicate edges removed Invalid handles NA values excluded Users follower threshold removed users follow followed within network resulting network forms cohesive community analysis.

title: Clean and trim network to create cohesive community ‚Äî trim_net
text: trimming process works iteratively: Remove duplicate connections invalid/missing handles Count followers user within network Remove users specified threshold Keep users appear followers followed Repeat network stabilizes creates "core community" every member meaningful connections within group, improving visualization quality analytical insights.

title: Clean and trim network to create cohesive community ‚Äî trim_net
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Build an initial network auth <- get_token("your.handle.bsky.social", "your-app-password") initial_net <- init_net(   c("scientist1.bsky.social", "researcher2.bsky.social"),   c("science", "research"),   auth$accessJwt )  # Expand the network expanded <- expand_net(   net = initial_net,   keywords = c("science", "research", "academic"),   token = auth$accessJwt,   refresh_tok = auth$refreshJwt,   threshold = 5,   max_iterations = 10 )  # Before trimming - show network size cat("Before trimming:") cat("  Unique actors:", length(unique(expanded$net$actor_handle))) cat("  Unique follows:", length(unique(expanded$net$follows_handle))) cat("  Total connections:", nrow(expanded$net))  # Trim to create cohesive community (need 10+ internal followers) trimmed_net <- trim_net(expanded$net, threshold = 10)  # After trimming - show the refined network cat("After trimming:") cat("  Unique users:", length(unique(trimmed_net$actor_handle))) cat("  Total connections:", nrow(trimmed_net))  # Verify all users both follow and are followed actors <- unique(trimmed_net$actor_handle) follows <- unique(trimmed_net$follows_handle) cat("Network cohesion check:") cat("  All actors also appear as follows:", all(actors %in% follows)) cat("  All follows also appear as actors:", all(follows %in% actors))  # Compare network density before and after users_before <- length(unique(c(expanded$net$actor_handle, expanded$net$follows_handle))) users_after <- length(unique(c(trimmed_net$actor_handle, trimmed_net$follows_handle))) density_before <- nrow(expanded$net) / (users_before * (users_before - 1)) density_after <- nrow(trimmed_net) / (users_after * (users_after - 1))  cat("Network density improved from", round(density_before, 4), "to", round(density_after, 4))  # Use proportional threshold for smaller networks # Require at least 20% of network to follow each user proportional_trim <- trim_net(initial_net, threshold = 0.2) } # }

what: Unfollow a user on Bluesky Social ‚Äî unfollow_actor
title: Unfollow a user on Bluesky Social ‚Äî unfollow_actor
text: Removes follow relationship account another user Bluesky Social. equivalent clicking "Unfollow" button user's profile. Requires record key follow relationship.

title: Unfollow a user on Bluesky Social ‚Äî unfollow_actor
code: unfollow_actor(my_did, rkey, token)

title: Unfollow a user on Bluesky Social ‚Äî unfollow_actor
text: my_did Character. decentralized identifier () obtained get_token response rkey Character. Record key follow relationship delete. Can obtained get_all_follow_records parsing URI follow_actor response token Character. Authentication token get_token

title: Unfollow a user on Bluesky Social ‚Äî unfollow_actor
text: httr2 response object confirming deletion, NULL unfollow operation fails.

title: Unfollow a user on Bluesky Social ‚Äî unfollow_actor
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Authenticate first auth <- get_token("your.handle.bsky.social", "your-app-password") token <- auth$accessJwt my_did <- auth$did  # Get all your follow records to find the one to delete all_follows <- get_all_follow_records(my_did, token)  # Find the record for a specific user target_profile <- get_profiles("example.bsky.social", token) target_record <- find_follow_record(all_follows, target_profile$did)  if (!is.null(target_record)) {   # Extract record key from URI (after the last slash)   rkey <- basename(target_record$uri)    # Unfollow the user   result <- unfollow_actor(my_did, rkey, token)    if (!is.null(result)) {     message("Successfully unfollowed user!")   } } } # }

title: Verify authentication token validity ‚Äî verify_token
text: Checks whether access token still valid making test API call Bluesky session endpoint. useful checking token expired making API calls.

title: Verify authentication token validity ‚Äî verify_token
code: verify_token(token)

title: Verify authentication token validity ‚Äî verify_token
text: token Character. Authentication token get_token refresh_token

title: Verify authentication token validity ‚Äî verify_token
text: Logical. Returns TRUE token valid active, FALSE token invalid, expired, revoked. Also prints message associated handle valid, error details invalid.

title: Verify authentication token validity ‚Äî verify_token
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Authenticate and verify token auth <- get_token("your.handle.bsky.social", "your-app-password") token <- auth$accessJwt  # Check if token is valid is_valid <- verify_token(token)  if (is_valid) {   # Token is good, proceed with API calls   profiles <- get_profiles("example.bsky.social", token) } else {   # Token expired, refresh it   new_auth <- refresh_token(auth$refreshJwt)   token <- new_auth$accessJwt }  # Can also use in conditional logic if (!verify_token(token)) {   stop("Please re-authenticate - your token has expired") } } # }

what: Calculate word frequencies from text data ‚Äî word_freqs
title: Calculate word frequencies from text data ‚Äî word_freqs
text: Analyzes collection texts (user profile descriptions) identify frequently used words word pairs (bigrams). Useful understanding common themes topics within network communities.

title: Calculate word frequencies from text data ‚Äî word_freqs
code: word_freqs(   texts,   bigrams = FALSE,   top = 30,   remove_stopwords = TRUE,   language = "en" )

title: Calculate word frequencies from text data ‚Äî word_freqs
text: texts Character vector. Texts analyze (e.g., user profile descriptions) bigrams Logical. TRUE, count word pairs instead individual words (default FALSE) top Integer. Number top frequent words/bigrams return (default 30) remove_stopwords Logical. Remove common stopwords like "", "" (default TRUE) language Character. Language stopword removal (default "en" English)

title: Calculate word frequencies from text data ‚Äî word_freqs
text: data frame word frequency statistics: feature Character. word bigram frequency Integer. Number occurrences rank Integer. Rank frequency (1 = frequent) docfreq Integer. Number documents containing feature group Character. Always "" function

title: Calculate word frequencies from text data ‚Äî word_freqs
code: # Sample user descriptions descriptions <- c(   "Data scientist working on machine learning projects",   "Climate researcher studying global warming effects",   "Marine biologist researching ocean ecosystems",   "Environmental data scientist analyzing climate patterns" )  # Get top words word_freq <- word_freqs(descriptions, top = 10) head(word_freq) #>     feature frequency rank docfreq group #> 1      data         2    1       2   all #> 2 scientist         2    1       2   all #> 3   climate         2    1       2   all #> 4   working         1    4       1   all #> 5   machine         1    4       1   all #> 6  learning         1    4       1   all  # Get top bigrams bigram_freq <- word_freqs(descriptions, bigrams = TRUE, top = 5) head(bigram_freq) #>             feature frequency rank docfreq group #> 1    data scientist         2    1       2   all #> 2 scientist working         1    2       1   all #> 3   working machine         1    2       1   all #> 4  machine learning         1    2       1   all #> 5 learning projects         1    2       1   all  if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # With real profile data from network analysis auth <- get_token("your.handle.bsky.social", "your-app-password") profiles <- get_profiles(c("user1.bsky.social", "user2.bsky.social"), auth$accessJwt) word_analysis <- word_freqs(profiles$description, top = 50) } # }

title: blueskynet 0.1.0
text: initial CRAN release - breaking changes previous versions
